items.item_details:
The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

items.item_details:
The Board will recognize Mr. Gary Cooper, who has been selected as one of CSEA's top 2012 Members of the Year. This is a great honor as only five members are awarded out of over 200,000 members statewide! The Member of the Year Awards Program will be held during CSEA's 86th Annual Conference on Thursday, August 2, at the Paris Hotel in Las Vegas, Nevada. The awards ceremony will be held in front of over 2,000 leaders, and Mr. Cooper, along with Chancellor Cepeda, will be given the opportunity to speak at the event.
	 
The Board of Trustees of the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District is very proud of Mr. Gary Cooper's selection of this award that recognizes his excellent work in support of the district and our students.
items.item_text: Recognition of Gary Cooper, One of CSEA's top 2012 Members of the Year

items.item_details:
The District employs non-bargaining unit employees in various categories to support programs and services.  These categories are: short-term assignments with limitations as defined in the CSEA/District collective bargaining agreement; substitutes to fill positions for employees on leave of absence or in vacant positions; professional experts with specialized knowledge or expertise not generally required of, or found within, the employee classifications established by the Governing Board; and athletic support staff for athletic activities.
	 
	 
WIN/CalWorks Program Position Establishment  
The establishment of the following position at EVC effective 05/23/12: 
Calworks Student Mentor
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the Short-Term Hourly, Substitute, Professional Expert & Athletic Support Services, Student Assistant and Volunteer personnel actions as submitted.

items.item_details:
The proposed courses and degree program have been reviewed by the appropriate instructional administrator and approved by the All-College Curriculum Committee, acting on behalf of the local Academic Senate.  The rigor of the approval process assures that each new course and degree program have substance and integrity in relation to its discipline and that it fills a clear student need not being served by existing course findings.  The list of the new courses and degree program are:
	 
ENGL 102L:  College Reading Lab
PSYCH 026:  Violence Against Women:  Cross-Cultural Perspective
Psychology, Associate in Arts Degree for Transfer

items.item_details:
Pursuant to Educational Code Section 5322 and Elections Code Section 13307 the Governing Board members must determine the content of the attached Specifications of the Election Order to send to the Santa Clara County Registrar of Voters.
	 
In addition, on January 10, 2006, the Board approved the following policy regarding filing fees for the office of District Trustee:
	 
BP 2140 Partial Reimbursement for Candidate Filing Fees
	 
The district shall reimburse the Registrar of Voters for 3/4s of the filing fees and the candidate would pay 1/4th of the filing fees.

items.item_details:
In October 2010, a team representing the Accrediting Commission for Community and Junior Colleges (ACCJC) conducted a comprehensive evaluation of San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College (EVC). The evaluation recommended, in part, (EVC 2004 Shared Recommendation 12) that the colleges should integrate the objectives of their technology plans into a District Technology Master Plan. Additionally, the evaluation determined, in part, (2010 Shared District Recommendation 1) that "the district, in collaboration with San Jose City College and Evergreen Valley College, should develop and implement a plan that will provide the necessary resources to increase college and district research capacity to analyze progress toward achieving institutional goals and objectives including improvements in student achievement and student learning."
	 
In November 2010, the voters approved Measure G - 2010, to provide $268 million to support the District's efforts toward upgrading its facilities and technology. Of this $268 million, $30 million is currently budgeted for technology upgrades.
	 
In order to respond to the ACCJC, to ensure that the District is maximizing the general obligation bond dollars allocated toward technology upgrades, and to continue its pursuit of institutional efficiencies, the District commissioned an assessment of its information technology support services in October 2011. The results of the assessment (attached) found the following: 
	 
Seasoned and experienced community college technology leadership is not present in the District.
Technology governance is not formalized.
Throughout the District, staff members are dedicated and hard-working.
Significant technology investments have not yielded expected results.
In user offices and in the technology area, a lack of consistency and standards prevents the District from achieving desired results.
Technology planning is not in evidence. As a result, the ability to leverage implementation decisions in order to appropriately scaffold results is impossible.
Students, faculty, and staff are underserved by the current state of the Datatel implementation.
The Datatel implementation has problems that require significant attention. Changing systems will not solve the underlying issues. In most cases, the functionality of Datatel is adequate.
Data-driven decision making is challenged by the lack of a well-crafted reporting architecture.
	 
In order for the District to transform its information technology support services into a pragmatic, results-oriented, service-focused, and stewardship-driven organization, the District issued a solicitation in March 2012 (attached) with the intent of engaging professional subject-matter experts to assist the District in meeting its technology needs. The scope of service included in the solicitation was:
	 
Develop and implement a best practice technology support model that ensures the appropriate deployment of all technology support. Provide day-to-day management oversight to the District Technology operations.
Develop and implement a long-term District Technology Plan aligned with the District's strategic objectives and operational needs based upon the District's Strategic Direction, Educational Master Plan, and Facilities Master Plan, including strategic, tactical, disaster recovery, business continuity, and information and data security plans.
Maximize the Datatel Colleague administrative system. Develop and implement policies, procedures, and training related to Datatel use. Assess, analyze, and bring online, as appropriate, unused or underutilized modules. Develop and implement a comprehensive business review process.
Manage and implement the District's technology projects funded by the District's Proposition 39 General Obligation Bonds (Measure G - 2010).
Improve the District's web presence.
Develop and implement a student email system that incorporates tools for collaboration.
Develop and implement a District intranet.
Improve online service delivery.
Develop and implement a network security plan.
Complete a system inventory and associated life cycle replacement plan and budget.
Review all technology-related contracts to identify potential cost savings as well as to identify vulnerabilities.
Attendance at, and assistance with meetings with the Board of Trustees, District Executive Team, Technology Leadership Group, vendors, and District staff.
Work collaboratively with other consultants and District staff. 
	 
The solicitation was sent to seven (7) potential vendors identified by surveying other bay area community colleges and from vendors currently on the District's list of potential vendors and placed in the legal advertisement section of the San Jose Post Record for two weeks. Of seven (7) potential vendors, two (2) submitted bids to the District and one (1) submitted a "no bid." The respondents were CampusWorks and Strata Information Group, Inc. (SIG).
	 
The two (2) bids were evaluated by a committee that included the Director of Fiscal Services, the Vice Chancellor of Human Resources, the Vice President of Administrative Services at EVC, the Executive Director of Research and Institutional Effectiveness, the District's IT Applications Manager, a FA Representative, a CSEA Representative, and a Purchasing Agent. Both vendors were selected to provide a presentation to the committee based upon the following criteria: Capacity to Perform (40%), Pricing (35%), References (20%), and Local and Small Business Preference (5%). 
	 
CampusWorks was selected to be recommended for award after negotiating the price down to $483,600 annually plus expenses set at 7% ($33,852) for a total annual price of $517,452. (The bid is attached for reference.) Additionally, CampusWorks has included an incentive-based fee structure. Under the arrangement, 10% of the contract cost will be set aside and released quarterly upon mutual agreement of the satisfactory completion of project milestones. The funding source for this endeavor is from the General Fund and Measure G - 2010, as appropriate. Furthermore, it is believed that the District will realize savings generated by a thorough review and re-negotiation of technology contracts, and savings attributable to better planning and management.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees award a contract not to exceed $517,452 annually to CampusWorks for strategic technology infrastructure services for a period of three years, subject to satisfactory performance, commencing July 1, 2012, with two optional one-year extensions.
items.item_text: Strategic Technology Infrastructure Services Selection
items.item_text_raw: 3. Strategic Technology Infrastructure Services Selection

items.item_details:
On May 8th the District Office Project Team presented three options for consideration for the future of the District Office. The presentation included a discussion on the relative costs associated with the three options, which included renovation of the existing District Office facility, construction of a new office facility on District owned property, and the purchase and renovation of an existing off-campus facility. Due to favorable market conditions and the high cost of new construction, the most economic option is to purchase an existing off-campus facility and renovate it to suit the needs of the District Office.
	 
Comments received from the Board on May 8th included several site selection criteria and a general concern about moving the District Office off-campus. The list of site criteria that the District Office Project Team will be considering to evaluate prospective properties will include:
Location 
Price 
Size 
Transportation proximity and accessibility
Parking amenities
Quality of structure and tenant improvements
Layout (single or multi-story)
Visibility of structure
Signage availability
Board Room accommodations
The Project Team also determined there are a total of seventy one (71) California Community College Districts. Twenty-two (22) of those are multi-college districts and twelve (12) of the multi-college districts are served by off-campus district offices.   
	 
RECOMMENDATION
The most economical solution points to relocation of the District Office to an off-campus facility. This option also appears to be the only option achievable within the current budget allocated to this project and results in the existing parcel being made available for development, allowing the District to realize an additional revenue generating potential of $450K to $700K annually, depending on the approved use of the parcel. 
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize staff to proceed with a search for new off-campus facilities to house District operations.
	 
PATH FORWARD
If authorization is granted to initiate the search for a new off-campus District Office facility, qualified candidate facilities will be identified and studied to determine the cost of adapting them to suit the District’s operational needs. Those meeting the District’s requirements will be presented to the Chancellor for consideration. Once a facility has been vetted by the Project Team and approved by the Chancellor, it will be presented to the Board for consideration.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees authorize staff to proceed with a search for new off-campus facilities to house District operations.

items.item_details:
This information item will provide a status update on the Measure G-2010 bond program, including background and history on the Program and Construction Management (PM/CM) selection process for the Measure G-2010 bond program, a review of Gilbane's performance through year one (FY2011/12) and information relating to the renewal of Gilbane's agreement for year two (FY2012/13). 
	 
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010 on November 2, 2010.  On January 25, 2011 a facilities and bonds study session served as an opportunity to share a framework for success for Measure G-2010. Included in this framework was the recommendation that the District utilize a program and construction management firm to provide program and construction management services to the colleges and District to support implementation of various construction and deferred maintenance projects. In keeping with the District's desire to promote accountability, efficiency and cost effectiveness, the District went through a formal Request for Qualifications process to seek the services of a Program and Construction Management firm to provide system-wide coordination and oversight of all capital improvement work performed under the Measure G-2010 bond program.  Gilbane Building Company was selected through this process.
	 
The initial one-year contract with Gilbane Building Company included program mobilization, scheduling, strategic program planning for implementation and design, and general program support at the campuses and the District. The first year contract was for time and materials only at a not-to-exceed amount of $2,166,832 with the option to renew the agreement annually through 2018.  The Board of Trustees approved the contract at the May 10, 2011 Board of Trustees meeting.
	 
The Board is being asked to review this information on May 22, 2012 and then take action on a year two (FY2012/13) contract renewal at the June 12, 2012 Board of Trustees meeting.
items.item_text: FY2012/13 Contract Renewal for Measure G-2010 Program/Construction Management Services with Gilbane Building Company - First Reading
items.item_text_raw: 2. FY2012/13 Contract Renewal for Measure G-2010 Program/Construction Management Services with Gilbane Building Company - First Reading

items.item_details: Information will be presented on the proposed Land Development Project for the 27 acres of District property adjacent to the Evergreen Valley College campus.  The information will include a review of the previous development activities, development principles previously established by the Trustees, availability of the land based on the 2025 EVC Facilities Master Plan, an overview of the real estate market conditions, City land use policies including current zoning, project development issues, key issues to pursue, and recommended next steps.
